threats.tagLine: Anthropogenic pressures on birds, habitats they rely on, and/or an entire ecosystem
threats.title: Coastal habitats in the region are feeling the pressure of sea level rise
threats.description:
• Marshes and beaches are being squeezed between rising seas and increasing development
  • Islands in the sounds and bays are eroding
  • Shorelines hardened with seawalls, roadways, and groins are accelerating erosion and habitat loss
  • Policies that support development in flood and storm-prone areas
  • Abundant and invasive predators

objectives.description: Expand Coastal Barrier Resources Act (CBRA) to incorporate  an additional 6000 acres in the Carolinas and modernize the statute to account for climate change impacts

actions.tagLine: Conservation interventions by Audubon field staff and partners as classifed by the Open Standards for the Practice of Conservation
actions.title: The Coastal Barrier Resources System saves lives, money and coastal resources
actions.description:
• Expand and modernize Coastal Barrier Resources Act (CBRA)
  • Material from dredging activity is used to reduce storm damage, promote public safety, restore habitat, enhance shorelines, promote recreation, and reduce disposal costs
  • Monitoring is needed to assess populations, demography, habitat use, and impacts of sea level rise on marsh-dependent species
  • Nature-based strategies or "green infrastructure" such as marshes, oyster beds and seagrass, can mitigate climate change impacts, and provide economic and environmental benefits to coastal communities

objectives.description: Protect and restore 200,000 acres of coastal marshes and marsh migration corridors
Increase volunteers at 30 sites and community engagement to improve and sustain long-term stewardship and advocacy programs

response.tagLine: Quantifying the effectiveness of our conservation actions using scientifically-sound metrics
response.title: American Oystercatcher productivity varies widely across the Coastal Carolinas landscape
response.description:
• Understanding the drivers of this variation will help us better manage the species
  • Recent research suggests that average productivity of 0.63 chicks per pair per year leads to stable populations1
  • American Oystercatcher abundance during winter appears to be stable1
response.footnotes:
1. Felton, S.K., N.J. Hostetter, K.H. Pollock and T.R. Simons 2017. Managing American Oystercatcher (Haematopus palliatus) population growth by targeting nesting season vital rates. Waterbirds, 40: 44-54
2. Audubon CBC 2017

partners.tagLine: Our work is co-developed and often led by partner organizations and stakeholders
partners.title: Audubon has established partnerships with 25 NGOs, state and federal agencies, and independent researchers to protect and restore the Coastal Carolinas landscape
partners.description: Audubon has a proven track record of working with the Army Corps of Engineers and states to use dredged material to restore habitat and recreation-dependent economies

objectives.description: Work with Audubonâ€™s network and other partners to advocate for at least 5 state and local solutions that protect key habitat areas through science and advocacy.
